1.text: I wish that you would be patient with me in a little foolishness, and indeed, you are!

2.text: Certainly, I am jealous over you with a godly jealousy: I betrothed you to one husband, so that I might present you as a pure virgin to Christ.

3.text: But I am afraid that somehow, just as the serpent deceived Eve in his shrewd deceit, so your minds might likewise be corrupted from the simplicity that is in Christ.

4.text: Somehow, if someone comes along preaching another Jesus (not the one we preached), or if you receive a different spirit (not the one you [first] received), or a different Good News (which is not the one you accepted), you put up with it well enough.

5.text: However, I do not consider myself inferior to the superlative apostles:

6.text: although I am unskilled in speech, I am not unskilled in knowledge. No, in every way, what we are has been revealed to you in all [these] things.

7.text: Or did I commit a sin in humbling myself so that you might be exalted, because I preached God’s Good News to you free of charge?

8.text: I ‘robbed’ other Churches, taking wages from them, so that I might serve you!

9.text: When I was present with you and found myself in need, I was not a burden on anyone because when the brothers came from Macedonia, they provided according to my need. In everything, I have refrained from being a burden to you, and I will continue to do so.

10.text: As the truth of Christ is in me, no one will stop me from this boasting in the regions of Achaia.

11.text: Why do I say this? Because I do not love you? God knows that I do!

12.text: But what I do, I will keep doing, in order that those who wish to boast as we do may have no such occasion.

13.text: As it is, such men are false apostles, deceitful workers, trying to pass themselves off as Christ’s apostles.

14.text: And this is no wonder: even Satan presents himself as an angel of light.

15.text: It is no great thing, then, if his servants also disguise themselves as servants of righteousness, and their end will be according to their works.

16.text: I say it again: may you not think that I am fool! But if you do, receive me still as foolish, so that I also may boast a little.

17.text: What I [now] speak, I do not speak according to the Lord, but in foolishness, in this confidence of boasting.

18.text: And since I see that many boast as humans do, I will also boast.

19.text: Yes, since you are wise, you bear with the foolish gladly!

20.text: In fact, you put up with someone who brings you into slavery, devours you, takes you captive, exalts himself, or strikes you on the face.

21.text: I say this to our shame: we were too weak for that! However, if anyone is bold (I speak in foolishness), I am bold as well.

22.text: Are they Hebrews? So am I! Are they Israelites? So am I! Are they Abraham’s seed? So am I!

23.text: Are they Christ’s servants? I am even more so (I speak as a fool)! I was in far more labors, beaten countless times, far more often in prisons, and often close to death.

24.text: Five times, I was beaten with stripes (forty times minus one) from the Jews.

25.text: Three times, I was beaten with rods. Once, I received a stoning. Three times, I suffered shipwreck and was for a night and a day in the open sea.

26.text: I have been in travels often, in danger from rivers, robbers, from my countrymen, from the Gentiles; in danger in the city, in the wilderness, at sea, among false brothers;

27.text: in toil and hardship, in vigils often, in hunger and thirst, often fasting, and in cold and nakedness.

28.text: Besides those things which are external, there is something that comes upon me daily: anxiety for all the Churches.

29.text: If anyone is weak, do I not feel weak too? If anyone stumbles, do I not burn with indignation?

30.text: But if I must boast, I will boast about those things that have to do with my weakness.

31.text: The God and Father of our Lord Jesus Christ, he who is blessed unto the ages, knows that I do not lie.

32.text: In Damascus, the governor of King Aretas guarded the city, desiring to arrest me.

33.text: But I was let down in a basket along the wall through a window, and this is how I escaped from his hands.
